questions.question: Which anion gives effervescence with dilute HCl, producing a gas that turns limewater milky?
questions.explanation: CO₃²⁻ + 2H⁺ → CO₂(g) + H₂O. CO₂ turns limewater milky: Ca(OH)₂ + CO₂ → CaCO₃ + H₂O

questions.question: Which anion gives a white precipitate with acidified BaCl₂ that is insoluble in acids?
questions.explanation: SO₄²⁻ + Ba²⁺ → BaSO₄(s) white precipitate, insoluble in acids.

questions.question: Which anion gives a yellow precipitate with AgNO₃ that is insoluble in dilute NH₃?
questions.explanation: I⁻ + Ag⁺ → AgI(s) yellow precipitate, insoluble in dilute NH₃.

questions.question: Which anion gives a cream precipitate with AgNO₃ that is partly soluble in concentrated NH₃?
questions.explanation: Br⁻ gives cream AgBr precipitate, partly soluble in concentrated NH₃ but not in dilute NH₃.

questions.question: Which anion gives a brown ring at the interface when tested with FeSO₄ and conc. H₂SO₄?
questions.explanation: Brown ring test for NO₃⁻: NO₃⁻ + Fe²⁺ + H₂SO₄ → brown [Fe(NO)]SO₄ ring.

questions.question: Which anion decolorizes acidified potassium manganate(VII) solution?
questions.explanation: SO₃²⁻ reduces purple MnO₄⁻ to colourless Mn²⁺: 5SO₃²⁻ + 2MnO₄⁻ + 6H⁺ → 5SO₄²⁻ + 2Mn²⁺ + 3H₂O

questions.question: Which anion gives a white precipitate with AgNO₃ that dissolves in dilute NH₃?
questions.explanation: Cl⁻ gives white AgCl precipitate, soluble in dilute NH₃ forming [Ag(NH₃)₂]⁺ complex.

questions.question: Which anion produces a colourless gas with dilute HCl that smells of rotten eggs?
questions.explanation: S²⁻ + 2H⁺ → H₂S(g) which has a characteristic rotten egg smell.
